message.content: This question requires an understanding of the concept of extinction. When a species of plant or animal ceases to exist on Earth, it is considered extinct. Extinction is a permanent loss and cannot be undone. Option (A) is incorrect because extinction is not reversible. Option (C) contradicts the definition of extinction. Option (D) is incorrect because a subspecies refers to a subdivision of a species, but this question is asking about the loss of a species.

This question requires understanding of the concept of extinction. When a species of plant or animal ceases to exist on earth, it is considered extinct. Extinction is a permanent loss and cannot be undone. Option (A) is incorrect because extinction is not reversible. Option (C) is incorrect because the loss is not reversible. Option (D) is incorrect because a subspecies refers to a distinct population within a species, not the loss of a species itself.

This question requires knowledge about the concept of extinction. When a species of plant or animal ceases to exist on Earth, either naturally or due to human activities, it is considered extinct. Extinction means that the species is gone forever and cannot be brought back. Option (A) is incorrect because extinction is not reversible. Option (C) is also incorrect because extinction is not reversible. Option (D) does not make sense in the context of the question as it refers to a different concept than extinction.

This question requires knowledge about the concept of extinction. When a species of plant or animal becomes extinct, it means that there are no remaining individuals of that species alive. Extinction is a permanent and irreversible loss. Option (A) is incorrect because extinction by definition cannot be reversed. Option (C) is incorrect as well because extinction is not reversible. Option (D) is incorrect because a subspecies refers to a population within a species that has distinct characteristics but is still part of the same species. Extinction refers to the complete disappearance of a species, not just a subspecies.

This question requires some understanding of the concept of extinction and the irreversible nature of species loss. If a species ceases to exist, either naturally or because of human activities, it cannot be undone. Once a species goes extinct, it is gone forever and cannot be restored or reversed. Option (A) is incorrect because extinction is not reversible. Option (C) is also incorrect because the loss of a species is not reversible. Option (D) is unrelated because a subspecies refers to a distinct population within a species, not the entire species.

Option (C) is incorrect because it contradicts the previous statement about irreversible loss. Option (D) is incorrect because the question does not refer to a subspecies, but a species as a whole.

Option (A) is incorrect because extinction, by definition, is not reversible. Option (C) is also incorrect because it contradicts the definition of extinction. Option (D) is unrelated because a subspecies is a distinct population within a species, and the question is asking about the loss of an entire species.
